newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- FEB 19.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- FEB 19.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--Reliable sources report that Greece and the governments of its EU partners are working on a plan to improve Turkey's relations with the European Union on the condition that better ties lead to a a reduction in tension between Ankara and Athens.The plan would be to extend further funds to Ankara and have it cooperate in a number of committees in return for Ankara accepting a July 15, 1996 EU Council text on prerequisites for relations with the EU, beginning procedures to take Greek-Turkish differences to the International Court and substantial dialogue on a resolution of the Cyprus issue. Washington's efforts are geared in the same direction.

--Conservative opposition party New Democracy is looking for a third leadership candidate in the hope of neutralising the "divisive candidacies" of incument Miltiades Evert and hopeful George Souflias. A dinner to discuss the issue at the home of ND deputy president Ioannis Varvitsiotis last night was attended by 30 ND MPs.

--The confusion continues over the government's new E9 form, to be completed by taxpayers to calculate the new real estate tax. Yesterday, property owners said the possible processing of the E9 by private firms would endanger taxation caonfidentiality.

--The strong downward tendency of inflation will continue this month, bringing with it new opportunities for lower interest rates. Initial indications show inflation dropping to 6.5 percent from 6.8 percent in January.

--Deputy Foreign Minister Yannos Kranidiotis was informed of a NATO initiative to install hot lines in Ankara, Athens and NATO's Brussels headquarters to avert any crises between the two feuding NATO allies at the NATO meeting in Brussels yesterday.

--Striking teachers and the government have clashed over their numbers: union head Nikos Tsoulias said he would resign if the figures cited by Deputy Finance Minister Nikos Christodoulakis on wages for new teachers were accurate. Teachers yesterday decided on a sixth week to their strike.
--The car bomb attack in Iraklion, Crete, yesterday, which cost the wife of senior police officer Kostas Soldatos a leg, was aimed at a police officer known for tracking down organised crime.
--The majority of Greeks support the government's handling of the casino issue, with 67.8 percent saying they do not want privately-run casinos.

--The dynamite used in the booby-trapped car of Iraklion police chief Soldatos probably came from an army camp, investigators say. The inquiries have turned to underworld figures as well as loan sharks bothered by the activities of Officer Soldatos.
--Homebuyers will soon be facing a wealth of choices as lending interest rates fall in the wake of lower inflation.
--A mass grave of Greek fighters on the Albanian front during WWII has been found in the neighbouring country. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
